awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase I: iPerform - I/UCRC for Assistive Technologies to Enhance Human Performance
awd_abstract_narration:
The I/UCRC for Assistive Technologies (AT) will attract support for the advancement of AT research and promote innovation in academia that is driven by industrial needs. In work environments, ATs can improve work efficiency, identify safety risks, shorten the learning curve or worker training through simulations, and improve resource allocation, creativity and communication. In healthcare environments, AT tools can enhance sensory and cognitive capabilities, improve training & delivery, enable remote monitoring, delay physical and cognitive decline in chronic conditions, personalize rehabilitation, predict risks for the elderly who live alone, monitor sleep disorders, design better prosthetics or drugs, design better robotic assistants, smart wheelchairs, therapy games and tools to monitor mental/physiological conditions, such as depression, epilepsy, or heart problems. The seed projects conducted within the center will help advance basic research in computer vision, machine learning, user interfaces, brain imaging, human robot interaction, human computer interaction, virtual reality, simulation, and many other related research areas.

The projects conducted at I/UCRC for Assistive Technologies will drive a broad spectrum of advances in the areas such as worker productivity and safety, transportation, health, company operations and intelligence, and promote the development of AT research infrastructure. The center addresses real-world problems and thus can generate new jobs, products, services, and impact all areas where a human has the potential to improve. The center will play role in enhancing the quality and diversity of AT professionals and prepare a future generation of competitive employees-scientists who can solve problems due to unmet human needs. Through compelling projects, the center will also attract students to CSE fields. UTA and UTD have a strong record in training students and have ongoing NSF projects, e.g., to identify software errors, analysis of facial expressions to identify arthritic pain, or efficient multimodal database searches.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Report for NSF Grant Federal Award ID: 1439645 

Award Title: I/UCRC Phase I: iPerform - I/UCRC for Assistive Technologies to Enhance Human Performance

Awardees: University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) and University of Texas at Dallas (UTD)

Center PIs: Fillia Makedon (UTA) and Ovidiu Daescu (UTD)

UTA PI/Co-PI Names: Fillia Makedon (PI), Vassilis Athitsos, G. Das, H. Jiang, S. Wang

Report Submission Period: 09/01/2021 to 05/31/2022

Managing Program Officer: Behrooz Shirazi (bshirazi@nsf.gov) 703-292-8343

 

Introduction

The mission of the iPerform IUCRC center is to research and develop Assistive Technologies (AT) that overcome physical, cognitive and operational obstacles and  prevent a human from reaching his/her full potential at home, at work and in public contexts. Ats are computer aided tools and methods to increase, maintain, or improve the functional capabilities of people with disabilities, as well as to enhance the productivity of well-bodied people. AT devices include sensors, robots, and wearables.  The iPerform Center research uses AI methods to recognize important elements of human behavior that can be used to provide targeted rehabilitation, personalized training, efficient information sharing and enhancement of performance.­­ AT methods include Artificial Intelligence algorithms (e.g., machine learning, data mining), virtual and augmented reality, analysis of human sensing and biometric data, and other.

 

Motivation

Although Assistive Technologies have been researched by academia and industry, there has not been a comprehensive and systematic effort to bridge academic research outcomes with industrial needs for innovation and commercialization, enhance basic research, and advance learning important to improving the quality of life.  The iPerform I/UCRC center has performed a dual role: (a) to support academic AT research that leads to innovation driven by industrial needs and (b) attract commercial interest that leads to the development and commercialization of new products that help maintain US competitiveness.

 

Summary of Activities

During the award period, center PIs identified companies interested in AT research and development. They organized bi-annual meetings where companies were invited and research presentations were made. The center’s website (iPerform.uta.edu) was maintained to inform to attract interested companies become center members. Many individual meetings with company representatives took place to identify opportunities for joint research, development and commercialization. Center researchers presented research findings in many peer review conferences and published in journals. Many opportunities were identified that were connected to the strengths of the two center universities, UTA and UTD, and included:  NSF-funded research on disabilities, in-place aging, rehabilitation; therapy tools for depression, cyberphysical systems, cybersecurity, machine learning, data mining, big data analysis, software engineering, and embedded systems.  Eight Ph.D. students graduated at UTA working on center projects and 12 REU students were trained and engaged in center research.  In addition, a postdoc who became part of the center, received mentoring and was able to secure a tenure track faculty position at Santa Clara University. 

Project Outcomes and Findings

Through the UTA and UTD respective Industrial Advisory Boards, as well as directly with national and international companies, there were many industrial memberships secured. UTA secured nine industrial memberships over the period of the grant which have included the companies AT&T, NetApp, VA of North Dallas, VA of New Jersey, National Center for Scientific Research Demokritos, FoxConn, Texas Instruments, Barrett Technologies and Agillaire. In addition, UT Dallas memberships included SPEETRA, Raytheon, Bosch, NIST, and others.

 

Intellectual Merit

The center promoted innovation in academia driven by industrial needs. Research and development was conducted that improved work efficiency, shortened the learning curve of training, improved resource allocation, creativity and communication, enhanced human sensory and cognitive capabilities, produced better designs for different therapies, advanced research in robotics and human robot collaboration. Research outcomes focused on big data analytics, cybersecurity, machine learning, intelligent user interface design and databases.

Broader Impacts

Center research developed products that impact the quality of human life, reduce healthcare and productivity costs and enhance industrial and academic innovation in many areas. Below are example applications that illustrate the center’s broader impacts:

  1. 1.     Manufacturing: Tools were developed to improving efficiency in the workplace, identify safety risks, shorten the learning curve through training simulations, improve resource allocation, and support persons with disabilities.
  2. 2.     Healthcare: Systems to enhance the performance of healthcare workers, improve healthcare training and delivery, enable remote monitoring, provide personalized rehabilitation, design smart therapy games, diagnose and treat sleep disorders, research the impact of cognitive and physical fatigue.
  3. 3.     Learning and training: tools to improve and shorten the learning curve of individuals in different contexts.
  4. 4.     Data analytics and Big Data related to human performance analysis: Software to improve the analysis of collected data.
  5. 5.     Cybersecurity and privacy: Tools to ensure that information and data sharing remains secure.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/09/2022
Modified by: Fillia S Makedon
